lexUnit.name: deplore.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: feel or express strong disapproval of.

sentence.text: The US deplored the assassination as a ` despicable act of terrorism against a man of peace . "
Elizabeth Nihell deplored the growing fashion for men-midwives .
Robbie listened uncomfortably , deploring the fiction about Hugh that she 'd allowed to continue .
I deplore the recent attacks by Ministers and others on the association and what it is doing .

Andreeva began by welcoming the more open atmosphere in which her students were discussing all kinds of issues , but deplored the way in which the Soviet past had become identified with mistakes and shortcomings .
Betty deplored the cuts in the education budget and Beuno lit a cigarette .
We deplore attacks in either direction across the border .
UN deplores invasion as ` violation of international law " US defied by Vatican on Noriega ..
In Rome , the Vatican deplored the vote as ` a grave new obstacle " to church reconciliation .
Kim Il Sung presented a report in which he deplored the division of Korea , which was itself attributable to the machinations of the Americans .
Much as I may deplore it , for the moment you 're very much my responsibility . "
I rather deplore the recent manifestation of Pop ; it does n't seem to me to have the intellectual force of the art of the Sixties .
The Catholic bishops of Malawi have launched their own ` Liberation Theology " that deplores official repression .
He deplored the materialistic trend of education : " Teach language , speech and trades " , and asked rhetorically , " What about religion ? "
The fraudulent conduct of the poll , and the subsequent annullment , was deplored by the former President , Mr Jimmy Carter .

In general the practice of searching wrecks for treasure is deplored by the Museum : in most cases no provision is made for properly recording where items were located ; only items of commercial value are salvaged and there is no interest in the wreck as an entity or the long-term conservation issues involved in raising perishable items such as iron and wood from the sea bed .
Marriage and religion were discussed and deplored .

Bonuses are not wholly to be deplored .
We deplore the fact that this drug causes the death of unborn human beings and we express our grave concern that it will damage women physically and psychologically . "
Aylwin stated that he " deplored the incident " and expressed his " solidarity " with Kohl .
He was also ready to acknowledge the failures of bureaucracy and deplored an organisation of ` little cogs , little men , clinging to little jobs and striving towards bigger ones . "
By the way , I deplore the practice employed by some filling stations of having several premium unleaded pumps on the forecourt but tucking the standard and cheaper fuel , away in a corner .
` But I deplore the thought that very large chunks of public expenditure could be devoted to people who are no more dependent on farming for their livings than you or me . "
This situation was not , until very recently , deplored very widely by anyone but some librarians .
It was reported that over-ripe tomatoes and some oldish eggs had been tossed at the door of two southern commercial stations , which was a smear tactic we deplored with emphasis .

He said he deplored the abandonment of learning the rules of grammar by rote and stressed that higher standards of literacy were needed if Britain was to compete in an increasingly competitive world .

Like everyone else , I deplore and condemn this killing , as all right-thinking people must .
The Foreign Office deplored ` the infringement of human rights in Malawi " .
The speed of change which Professor Hoskins deplored is well brought out here by his remarks about a stopping train through Rutland .
